the Death of two Emperours Severus, and Conſtantius Chlorus, as alſo for the Nativity of Conſtantine the Great.
Yſtwich, in Card. perhaps from the C. Br. Yſtwith, bound up, from the barrenneſs of the Land, which giveth but ſmall increaſe.
Ythell, a Welſh Chriſt. Name; a Contract of the Gr. Euthalius.
Yutland, in the Teut. Iutland; a part of Cimb. Cherſoneſus, q. d. the Gothick Land, or the Land of the Goths.

ZEaland, in the Belg. Zeeland, and Seeland, a Province both of the Netherlands, and Daneland, the one was the Seat of the ancient Codani, the other of the Mattiaci, q. d. in Eng. Sea Land, ſo called from its Situation; becauſe the Sea formerly waſhed it on both ſides.
Zouch, a Sirname, (i. e.) de la Zouche; the Fr. Zouche, denotes a Trunk of a Tree.
Zutphen, a Town and Country in the Netherlands, q. d. Southfen; ſee South, and Fen in the Common Names.
Zuyder Zee, between Zealand, and Holland, (q. d.) in Engliſh the Southern-Sea, that is with reſpect to Holland, which it waſheth on the South ſide; ſee South, and S • a, in the Com. Names.

div.head: Proper Names of Men and Women now commonly uſed, coming from the Hebrew, Greek, and Latin, truly derived, with the Signification of the Name in the Original; together with the Name, as 'tis both in Hebrew and Greek in their reſpective Characters; very uſeful for Young Scholars.

list.item:
AAron, the ſame in all Languages: In the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which comes from the root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a Mountain. In the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Aaron. By interpretation, belonging to the Mountains.
Abel, the ſame in all Languages. Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Abel. By interpretation, Vanity.

Abraham, the ſame in all Languages. Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , father, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , high, God himſelf adding the letter 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that the name ſhould ſignifie a Multitude, he having promis'd to Abraham a numerous iſſue. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Abraham, or Abrahamus; q.d. renown'd or honoured Father.

Adam, the ſame in all Languages: In the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , from the root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he was aſham'd. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Adam or Adamus. It ſignifies originally, ſhame.

Aeneas, the ſame with the Lat. Aeneas, which comes immediately from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which again may be deriv'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. e. from praiſe, q. d. praiſe worthy, or commendable.

Agar or Hagar, from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which comes from the Verb 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to go on pilgrimage, to fly. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Hagar. By interpretation, a Stranger, Traveller, or Pilgrim.

Alexander, from the Lat. Alexander, this immediately from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is drawn from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to help, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the Gen. of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a man; q. d. a manly or valiant helper or aſſiſtant.

Amon; in the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Amon, all the ſame, derived more immediately from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which in Niphal ſignifies, to be true or faithful.

Amos; In Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Amos, all the ſame; It ſignifies originally ſtout or ſtrong
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , robuſtus fuit is the radix of it.
Andrew, derived from the Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or the Lat. Andreu, which is again drawn 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for his Courage and Manlineſs.

BAptiſt, a Chriſten-Name of a Man; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or the Lat. Baptiſta, i. e. a Baptizen, perhaps the firſt among the Greeks that uſed that Office, they call'd Baptiſt, which might afterwards by common uſe grow into a Proper Name; as we often find Names deriv'd from Office: for inſtance Ʋſher, which before was Noel, by being Gentleman Uſher to King John, took his Name with his Office. John the Baptiſt.
Barbara, a Womans Chriſten-Name; from the Lat. Barbara.

Barnabas, In the Syriack 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Barnaba, Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Barnabas, derived from the Syr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bar, a Son, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nabi, comfort, q. d. the Son of Conſolation; for ſo he is call'd in Act. 4.36. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , one main gift of a Prophet being placed in Conſolation and Exhortation.

Bartholomew, in the Syr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Bartholomai, derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bar, a Son, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , thole, hanging or leaning downward, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Majim, waters: q. d. the Son of a Water-drawer: Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Bartholomaeus.
Benedict, a Womans Chriſten-Name; from the Lat. Benedicta idem. It ſignifies, ſhe is bleſſed.

Benjamin, of an Hebr. original, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ben, a Son, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
jamin, the right hand. q.d. the Son of my right hand, i. e. as dear to me as my right hand. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Benjamin, all the ſame.
Bennet, a Man's Name, from the Lat. Benedictus, i. e. he is bleſſed.
Bettrice, or Beatrice, the Name of a Woman; from the Lat. Beatrix, She that Bleſſeth, a woman Bleſſer.

CAeſar; From the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or the Lat. Caeſar, theſe from the Lat. caeſaries, that is, hair, wherewith he was born: or à caeſiis oculis, from his Gray Eyes: But moſt probably à caeſo matris utero, from his Mothers Belly being cut before ſhe could be deliver'd of him.
Charity, from the Lat. Charitas, this from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id.
Catharine, the Name of a Woman, from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ſo call'd q. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. e. pure or chaſt.
Chriſtian, from the Lat. Chriſtiana, i. e. belonging to Chriſt.

Chriſtopher, from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Chriſt, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to ſuffer or endure; q. d. I bear Chriſt, according to the Fable of St. Chriſtopher's, carrying Chriſt on his back through the Sea. He Preached the Goſpel in Lycia, and was Beheaded under Diocleſian the Emperor.

Chryſoſtom, from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or the Lat. Chryſoſtomus; which are deriv'd from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , golden, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a mouth, q. d. golden mouth, ſo call'd, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , for his extraordinary Eloquence. He was Biſhop of Conſtantinople in the year 401.
Cicely, a Womans Name, from the Lat. Caecelia.
Clare, a Womans Name, from the Lat. Clara, clear.

Clemens, a Roman Name, ſignifying one mild and benign; from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , glory, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the mind; Clemency being truly the glory of the mind. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Cornelius, derived to us from the Lat. Cornelius, which may come from the Lat. Cornu, a horn; or more likely q. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. e. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a beam of the Son.

DAniel, from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is again compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Judge, (which comes of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to judge) and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , God; q. d. the judge of God. In Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Lat. Daniel.

David, from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which comes from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
dodh, beloved, q. d. beloved of God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. David.

Denis or Dennis, the Proper Name both of a Man and Woman; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , q. d. belonging to Bacehus; theſe from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Bacchus, which is again derived from Dia, one of the Iſlands of the Cyclades, conſecrated to him after his Marriage with Ariadne, and the City Nyſas wherein he reign'd; Or from Du or Dy, i. e. Lord, and Nyſa by a Metatheſis for Sina, q.d. Lord of Sina, ſays Lloyd.
Deodate, a Man's Name; from the Lat. Deod • us, i. e. given of God, or given to God.
Dorcas, a Womans Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . It ſignifies originally a wood or wild Goat.
Dorothy, a Womans Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a gift, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a Goddeſs; q. d. the gift of a Goddeſs.

ELeazar, a Man's Name, from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Eliezer; this again from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 God, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 help; q. d. the help of God; or rather God of help, or help from God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Eleazar, id.

Eliſabeth, a Womans Name, from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Eliſchebah; this again from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 God, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
in Niphal, he hath ſworn; q. d. God hath ſworn. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Elizabetha, Eliza, or Eliſabet. id.

Enos, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a Man, which comes from the root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
to be ſick; for man is infirm and ſubject to many Diſeaſes. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Enos, id.
Ephraim, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 id. It ſignifies in the original unfruitful. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Ephraim, or Ephraimus.

Eve, a Womans Name, originally from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Chava, ſo call'd becauſe ſhe was the Mother of all Living. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Eva, id.
FElix, a Man's Name; from the Lat. Felix happy: It anſwers the Gr. Macarius.

GAbriel, the Name of a Man; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
id. which is again derived from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to prevail, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 God, q. d. to prevail with God: Or q. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. e. the man of God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Gabriel, id.

George, the Name of a Man; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and this from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the Earth, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to incite or ſtir up; q. d. a Ploughman or Tiller of the Ground. In Lat. Georgius.

Gregory, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which may poſſibly be drawn from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
to watch, q. d. watchful, as was Gregory the Great, being almoſt in continual ſtudy.

HIerom or Ierom, the Name of a Man; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and this again poſſibly, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
holy, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a Law.

IAcob, a Man's Name; originally in the Hebr. call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
jahakohh; from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 the heel; ſo call'd, becauſe being twin-brother to Eſau, he held him by the heel with his hand in the Birth, which Hieroglyphick was afterwards verify'd in his ſupplanting his Brother, and getting the Bleſſing and Inheritance for himſelf.
Iames, the ſame with Iacob above.

Ieremy, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 to exalt, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Jehovah, the Lord; q. d. one that will magnifie the Lord. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Jeremias, id.

Iob, the Name of a Man; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Ijob, this from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
to indure injuries, or, ſuffer affronts, q.d. patient. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Job, or Jobus, id.

Iohn, a Man's Name; originally in the Hebr. it was 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Jehochanan, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Jochanan, compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
jehovah, the Name of God Almighty, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
grace, which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
he hath been gracious; by interpretation as above it ſignifies, the grace of God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Johannes, id.

Ionas or Ionah, the Name of a Man. Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Jonah (which alſo ſignifies a Dove or Pidgeon), derived foom the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
janah, he or it oppreſſed or afflicted; for a Dove through its harmleſneſs becomes a prey to the more Ravenous Fowls that with ſtrength oppreſs it. Jonah ſignifies a Dove-like temper of mind. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Jonas, id.

Ioſeph, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
id. this from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he hath added. It ſignifies, he doth, or may add, purſuant to his Mother Rachel's deſiring God to give her more Sons. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Joſephus, id.

Ioſias, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Ioſchijahu, which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , fire, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Jehovah, Lord; q. d. the fire of the Lord. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Joſias, id.

Iſaac, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id. this from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he laughed; the word Iſaac in the Original ſignifies, he ſhall, or, he will laugh. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Iſaacus or Iſaac, id.
LEttice, a Womans Name; from the Lat. Laetitia, which ſignifies Joy, Gladneſs, or Glee.
Love, a Womans Name; 'tis of an Engliſh Original, and render'd in Lat. by Amorea.

Lucrece, a Womans Name; derived from the Lat. Lucretia, which was the Name of the Roman Dame, that for the Rape committed upon her by Sixtus Tarquinius, ſtabb'd her ſelf in the preſence of her Husband, Father, and others.
Lucy, a Womans Name; from the Lat. Lucia, which may again be derived from the Lat. Luceo, to ſhine; or from Lux, light.

Luke, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is the ſame with Lucius of the Roman's, that is ſo call'd à Luce, from the Light, this Name being uſually given ſuch as were born juſt as the Sun riſes.

MAgdalen or Maudlin, a Womans Name; in the Syr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Magdeletha, that is, florid, creſcent or magnificent; this from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he was great or increaſed: Some ſay that Mary Magdalen was ſo call'd from Magdala, the name of the Village where ſhe lived. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Magdalene, id.
Margaret or Marget, a Womans Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , or the Lat. Margarita, a Pearl.

Mark, the Name of a Man; from the Lat. Marcus, which name among the Romans was uſually given to ſuch as were born in the Month of March; though ſome, without any ground (it being purely a Roman Name) go about to draw it from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Marak, he poliſh'd or beautify'd.
Martha, a Womans Name; It ſeems to be ſo call'd from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , bitterneſs. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Martha, id.

Mary, a Womans Name; originally 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Mirjam. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he was ſad, whence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ſhe was ſad. Now in the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and Lat. Maria, id.

Matthew, a Man's Name; in the Syr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Matthai, from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
he hath given, whence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a gift; ſo that it is ſo call'd quaſi Deo datus, i. e. given of God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Matthaeus, id.

Michael, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , who, the Adverb of Similitude 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
God; q.d. who is like God? Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Michael id.

Moſes, a Man's Name; originally in the Hebr. call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Moſche, i. e. drawn out, the firſt of the Name being drawn out of the water by Pharaoh's Daughter. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Moſes, or Moyſes, id.
NAthan, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which originally ſignifies, he gave. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Nathan, id.

Nathanael, a Man's Name; the ſame in the Hebr. compounded of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he gave, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , God, q.d. God gave him. It anſwers the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Nathanaël, id.

Nicholas, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , victory, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , the People, q. d. a ſubduer or tamer of the People. Lat. Nicholaus.
OLiver, a Man's Name; in Lat. Olivarius; perhaps from the Lat. Oliva; or the Eng. Olive.

PAul, firſt Saul, whence by the Hebr. call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Schaul, which comes from the Root. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
he begg'd; (as a Priſoner for Life;) and the word being of a Latin original, is by interpretation Puſillus, a Daſtard or Coward. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Paulus, id.

Peter, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , this again from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Rock; for that our Saviour ſaid to the bleſſed Apoſtle of that Name (he being before call'd Cephas) On this Rock will I build my Church, i. e. on Peter. Lat. Petrus, id.

Philip, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and this again from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a lover, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Horſe; q. d. warlike, one that delights in Horſes. Lat. Philippus, id.
Priſcilla, a Womans Name; of a Latin Original, and may ſeem to come from priſca, ancient, this being a Diminutive thereof. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , id.
RAchel, a Womans Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which originally ſignifies, a ſhe-Lamb. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Rachel, id.

Rebecca, a Womans Name; originally 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Ribhka, which comes from the old Root, now out of uſe, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of which comes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bloody, or fatted, or pamper'd, as a Calf for the Shambles. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Rebecca, id.

Ruben, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Reubhen, i e. the Son of Viſion. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Ruben, id.

SAmuel, a Man's Name; in Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Schemuel, i. e. heard of God; from the Root 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he heard, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
God; for that his Father Elcana begg'd the firſt of that Name of God. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Samuel, id.

Sarah, a Womans Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Sara, which ſignifies as much as Lady or Princeſs. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Sara, id.
Simon, a Man's Name; from the Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , he hath heard; which implies Obedience. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Lat. Simon, id.

Stephen, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is again derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , whence 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to crown with a Garland, &c. It ſignifies a Crown or Garland. Lat. Stephanus, id.
Suſan or Suſanna, a Womans Name; poſſibly from the Hebr. Noun 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Lily, it being certainly of an Hebr. Original. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Suſanna, id.

THeodore, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is derived from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , God, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Gift; q. d. the gift of God. Lat. Theodorus, id.

Theophilus, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which comes again from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , I love; q.d. beloved of God; or a Lover of God. Lat. Theophilus, id.

Thomas, a Man's Name; originally in the Syr. call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Thaumo, in Hebr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 i. e. twofold: for this reaſon Thomas was call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , of two hearts, becauſe of his doubting; he would believe, and he would not. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Thomas or Thoma, id.

Timothy, a Man's Name; from the Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and this again from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , to honour, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , God; q.d. a Worſhipper or Honourer of God. Lat. Timotheus, id.
VIncent, a Man's Name; from the Lat. Vincentius, this from vinco, to overcome; or from vincio, to bind.
Vrſula, a Womans Name; from the Lat. Ʋrſula, which originally ſign. the little Bear, a Conſtellation ſo call'd.

ZAchary, a Man's Name; in the Hebr. it was call'd 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Secharja, which ſign. the memory of the Lord. Gr. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Lat. Zacharias.

div.p: Obſerve that moſt, if not all, Proper Names of Men and Women, not found in this Appendix, occurr in the preceding Etymology of Proper Names.
